var.concept: Current or Recent Family Planning Use Variables -- PERSON

var.name: FPBEGINUSECMC_1
var.labl: Date first used most recent or current method in century month
var.txt:
FPBEGINUSECMC reports the century month code (CMC) for when the respondent first used her most recent or current family planning method. The instructions in the questionnaire specify that the respondent must have been at least 10 years old and at least the age she was when she started using her first contraceptive method in the month and year that she reported.
Note that January is consistently the most common month across samples (see FPBEGINUSEMO). Due to the data entry format of the survey, if a respondent reported a year but not a month for when she started using her most recent family planning method, January was the default month.
Enumerators were instructed to enter the date as January 1st, 2020 (January 1st, 2030 for samples in 2019 or after) if the respondent did not give a response to the associated survey question. IPUMS has recoded these cases to "No response."
Century month codes (CMC) are particularly useful for checking the consistency of dates, calculating intervals between events, and imputing dates when the information for an event is missing or partially complete.
Century month codes (CMC) are calculated by multiplying by 12 the difference between the year of an event and 1900. The year 1900 was chosen as the reference period because all of the relevant events for PMA occurred during the twentieth or twenty-first centuries. The month of the event is added to the previous result in the following formula:
CMC = (Year - 1900) * 12 + Month For example, the CMC for June 2002 is:
CMC = (2002 - 1900) * 12 + 6 = 1230
In other words, 1,230 months have elapsed between January 1900 and June 2002. Starting with CMC figures, one can calculate the month and year using the following formulas:
Year = int( ( CMC - 1 )/12 ) + 1900
[int(x) is the integer part of x]
Month = CMC - ( ( Year - 1900 ) * 12 )
The information above is based on "Online Guide to DHS Statistics" (Rutstein and Rojas, 2006).
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.
var.concept: Current or Recent Family Planning Use Variables -- PERSON

Note that January is consistently the most common month across samples (see FPBEGINUSEMO). Due to the data entry format of the survey, if a respondent reported a year but not a month for when she started using her most recent family planning method, January was the default month.
Enumerators were instructed to enter the date as January 1st, 2020 (January 1st, 2030 for samples in 2019 or after) if the respondent did not give a response to the associated survey question. IPUMS has recoded these cases to "No response."
Century month codes (CMC) are particularly useful for checking the consistency of dates, calculating intervals between events, and imputing dates when the information for an event is missing or partially complete.
Century month codes (CMC) are calculated by multiplying by 12 the difference between the year of an event and 1900. The year 1900 was chosen as the reference period because all of the relevant events for PMA occurred during the twentieth or twenty-first centuries. The month of the event is added to the previous result in the following formula:
CMC = (Year - 1900) * 12 + Month For example, the CMC for June 2002 is:
CMC = (2002 - 1900) * 12 + 6 = 1230
In other words, 1,230 months have elapsed between January 1900 and June 2002. Starting with CMC figures, one can calculate the month and year using the following formulas:
Year = int( ( CMC - 1 )/12 ) + 1900
[int(x) is the integer part of x]
Month = CMC - ( ( Year - 1900 ) * 12 )
The information above is based on "Online Guide to DHS Statistics" (Rutstein and Rojas, 2006).
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: FPPLANWHEN_1
var.labl: When will start using FP method in the future
var.txt:
For women who are not currently using a family planning method but think they will use a method in the future, FPPLANWHEN reports when the woman thinks she will begin using the method.
Note that this variable reports only a specific unit of time, i.e. months or years, not the actual duration of the interval. The specific number of months or years is reported in FPPLANVAL. For women who reported they would wait months or years, users must use both FPPLANWHEN and FPPLANVAL to determine the exact amount of time that the woman thinks she will wait before beginning to use a family planning method.
Women who reported that they would begin using a method "soon / now" or "after the birth of this child" were not asked to report a value, and so are excluded from the universe of FPPLANVAL.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

catgry.labl: After the birth of this child

var.concept: Future Family Planning Use Variables -- PERSON

var.concept: Future Family Planning Use Variables -- PERSON

var.name: FPPLANVAL_1
var.labl: When will start using FP method in the future- value
var.txt:
For women who are not currently using a family planning method but think they will use a method in the future, FPPLANVAL reports when the woman thinks she will begin using the method.
Note that the codes in this variable are not reported in a specific unit of time i.e., months, or years. Rather, the unit of time in which the woman responded is reported in FPPLANWHEN. For women who reported they would wait months or years, users must use both FPPLANVAL and FPPLANWHEN to determine the exact amount of time that the woman thinks she will wait before beginning to use a family planning method.
Note that some respondents reported a year, such as 2025 or 2030, instead of the number of years or months.
Women who reported that they would begin using a method "soon / now" or "after the birth of this child" were not asked to report a value, and so are excluded from this universe.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.
var.concept: Future Family Planning Use Variables -- PERSON

For women who reported they would wait months or years, users must use both FPPLANVAL and FPPLANWHEN to determine the exact amount of time that the woman thinks she will wait before beginning to use a family planning method.
Note that some respondents reported a year, such as 2025 or 2030, instead of the number of years or months.
Women who reported that they would begin using a method "soon / now" or "after the birth of this child" were not asked to report a value, and so are excluded from this universe.

var.name: FPSTOPMO_1
var.labl: Month stopped using most recent method
var.txt:
FPSTOPMO reports the calendar month when the respondent stopped using her most recent family planning method. The instructions in the female questionnaire specify that the date given must be after the date given in FPBEGINUSEMO and FPBEGINUSEYR.
Note that for many samples, January has the highest recorded frequency. Due to the data entry format of some surveys, if a respondent reported a year but not a month for when she stopped using her most recent family planning method, January was the default month for FPSTOPMO. See the Questionnaire tab for more information.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.
var.concept: Discontinuation of Family Planning Variables -- PERSON

var.concept: Discontinuation of Family Planning Variables -- PERSON

var.name: FPSTOPYR_1
var.labl: Year stopped using most recent method
var.txt:
FPSTOPYR reports the calendar year when the respondent stopped using her most recent family planning method. The instructions in the female questionnaire specify that the date given must be after the date given in FPBEGINUSEMO and FPBEGINUSEYR.
Enumerators were instructed to enter the date as January 1st, 2020 (January 1st, 2030 for samples in 2019 or after) if the respondent did not give a response to the associated survey question. IPUMS has recoded these cases to "No response".
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.
var.codInstr: Values represent a year, except for the following codes: 9995 = Not interviewed (female questionnaire) 9996 = Not interviewed (household questionnaire) 9997 = Don't know 9998 = No response or missing 9999 = NIU (not in universe)
var.concept: Discontinuation of Family Planning Variables -- PERSON

var.concept: Discontinuation of Family Planning Variables -- PERSON

var.name: FPSTOPUSECMC_1
var.labl: Date stopped using recent method of FP in century month
var.txt:
FPSTOPUSECMC reports the century month code (CMC) for when the respondent stopped using her most recent family planning method. The instructions in the female questionnaire specify that the respondent must have been at least 10 and at least the age she started using her first contraceptive method in the month and year that she reported.
Note that for many samples, January has the highest recorded frequency (see FPSTOPMO). Due to the data entry format of some surveys, if a respondent reported a year but not a month for when she stopped using her most recent family planning method, January was the default month. See the Questionnaire tab for more information.
Enumerators were instructed to enter the date as January 1st, 2020 if the respondent did not give a response to the associated survey question. IPUMS has recoded these cases to "No response."
Century month codes (CMC) are particularly useful for checking the consistency of dates, calculating intervals between events, and imputing dates when the information for an event is missing or partially complete.
Century month codes (CMC) are calculated by multiplying by 12 the difference between the year of an event and 1900. The year 1900 was chosen as the reference period because all of the relevant events for PMA2020 occurred during the twentieth or twenty-first centuries. The month of the event is added to the previous result, using the following formula:
CMC = (Year - 1900) * 12 + Month For example, the CMC for June 2002 is:
CMC = (2002 - 1900) * 12 + 6 = 1230
In other words, 1,230 months have elapsed between January 1900 and June 2002. Starting with CMC figures, one can calculate the month and year using the following formulas:
Year = int( ( CMC - 1 )/12 ) + 1900
[int(x) is the integer part of x]
Month = CMC - ( ( Year - 1900 ) * 12 )
The information above is based on "Online Guide to DHS Statistics" (Rutstein and Rojas, 2006).
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.
var.codInstr:
FPSTOPUSECMC is a 4-digit variable that represents the century-month value (months since 1900) when the woman stopped using her most recent family planning method. The following values represent NIU (not in universe) or missing cases:
9995 = Not interviewed (female questionnaire) 9998 = No response or missing 9999 = NIU (not in universe)
var.concept: Discontinuation of Family Planning Variables -- PERSON

var.name: FIRSTWILLDECIDE_1

var.txt:

The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

This variable differs from FPDEFCONFLICT in that it emphasizes whether there might be conflict, whereas FPDEFCONFLICT emphasizes that the woman thinks there will be conflict if she used family planning.

var.name: FPUSPLAN_1

var.txt:
For women who were not using a family planning method at the time of the interview or pregnant, FPUSPLAN indicates whether they think they will use a method of family planning to delay or avoid pregnancy in the future. var.name: FPUSPLAN_NPREG_1
var.labl: Plan to use a method in the future - not pregnant
var.txt:
For women who were not pregnant and not using a method of family planning at the time of the interview, FPUSPLAN_NPREG indicates whether they think they will use a method of family planning to delay or avoid pregnancy in the future. The variable FPUSPLAN contains this information both for women who are currently pregnant and for women who are not pregnant.
Users may also be interested in FPUSPLAN_PREG, which indicates, for women who were pregnant at the time of the interview, whether they think they will use a method of family planning to delay or avoid pregnancy in the future.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.txt:
For women aged 15-19 who have ever had sexual intercourse, FIRSTSUB indicates whether the woman was under the influence of a substance the first time that she had sexual intercourse.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: WORKWK_1
var.labl: Has done work other than own housework in last 7 days
var.txt:
WORKWK reports whether the woman has done any work aside from her own housework in the last 7 days. This includes work that is not paid and activities like work on the family farm or in the family business, selling things at the market, or running a small business.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: CALENDARKE_1
var.labl: Contraceptive calendar (Kenya)
var.txt: CALENDARKE contains retrospective contraceptive calendar data for 3 years prior to the female interview for Kenya. These data are contained in a comma delimited reading from right to left chronologically. For Kenya 2019, this variable represents the 3 years prior to the female interview, starting in January 2017 going to the month of the interview (either November or December 2019). For Kenya 2020, this variable represents 3 years prior to the female interview, starting in January 2018 going to the month of the interview (either November or December 2020). See the Codes tab for a list of the codes and meanings. Our user note on calendar data contains Stata code to convert this string variable into wide or long form numeric variables.
var.codInstr: B = Birth P = Pregnant T = Pregnancy ended 0 = No family planning method used 1 = Female Sterilization 2 = Male Sterilization 3 = Implant 4 = IUD 5 = Injectables 7 = Pill 8 = Emergency Contraception 9 = Male Condom 10 = Female Condom 11 = Diaphragm 12 = Foam / Jelly 13 = Standard Days / Cycle beads 14 = LAM 30 = Rhythm method 31 = Withdrawal 39 = Other traditional methods

var.name: CALENDARKEWHY_1
var.labl: Contraceptive calendar - why stopped using (Kenya)
var.txt: CALENDARKEWHY contains retrospective calendar data for why the woman stopped using a family planning method for a period of time prior to the female interview for Kenya. These data are in parallel to the data contained in CALENDARKE, and are contained in a comma delimited string reading from right to left chronologically. For Kenya 2019, this variable represents the 3 years prior to the female interview, starting in January 2017 going to the month of the interview (either November or December 2019). For Kenya 2020, this variable represents 3 years prior to the female interview, starting in December 2017 going to the month of the interview (either November or December 2020). See the Codes tab for a list of the codes and meanings. Our user note on calendar data contains Stata code to convert this string variable into wide or long form numeric variables.
var.codInstr: 1 = Infrequent sex / husband away 2 = Became pregnant while using 3 = Wanted to become pregnant 4 = Husband / partner disapproved 5 = Wanted more effective method 6 = Side effects / health concerns 7 = Lack of access / too far 8 = Costs too much 9 = Inconvenient to use 10 = Up to God / fatalistic 11 = Difficult to get pregnant / menopausal 12 = Marital dissolution / separation 96 = Other 99 = NIU (not in universe)

var.name: RESULTPANEL_1
var.labl: Panel woman questionnaire result
var.txt: RESULTPANEL indicates whether or not the respondent who was interviewed in Phase 1 completed the female questionnaire in a later Phase, and, if not, the reason why not.

var.name: RESULTPANEL_2
var.labl: Panel woman questionnaire result
var.txt: RESULTPANEL indicates whether or not the respondent who was interviewed in Phase 1 completed the female questionnaire in a later Phase, and, if not, the reason why not.

var.name: PANELWOMAN_1
var.labl: Panel woman interviewed in Phase 1
var.txt:
PANELWOMAN indicates whether the record represents a woman who was interviewed in Phase 1 (baseline survey) of the longitudinal family planning survey.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: PANELWOMAN_2
var.labl: Panel woman interviewed in Phase 1
var.txt:
PANELWOMAN indicates whether the record represents a woman who was interviewed in Phase 1 (baseline survey) of the longitudinal family planning survey.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: HHPANELP1_1
var.labl: Panel woman lived in this dwelling in Phase 1
var.txt: For persons enumerated in Phase 2, HHPANELP1 indicates that a woman in the longitudinal family planning panel lived in the person's current physical dwelling at Phase 1 (the baseline survey).

var.name: HHPANELP1_2
var.labl: Panel woman lived in this dwelling in Phase 1
var.txt: For persons enumerated in Phase 2, HHPANELP1 indicates that a woman in the longitudinal family planning panel lived in the person's current physical dwelling at Phase 1 (the baseline survey).

var.name: NEWPANELFEM_1
var.labl: Woman enrolled in panel in Phase 2
var.txt:
For women who were not interviewed in the Phase 1 (baseline) survey, NEWPANELFEM indicates whether they were enrolled during Phase 2.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: NEWPANELFEM_2
var.labl: Woman enrolled in panel in Phase 2
var.txt:
For women who were not interviewed in the Phase 1 (baseline) survey, NEWPANELFEM indicates whether they were enrolled during Phase 2.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: HHPANELP2_1
var.labl: Panel woman from Phase 1 lives in this dwelling in Phase 2
var.txt: HHPANELP2 indicates whether a woman interviewed in Phase 1 was living in the dwelling in Phase 2.

var.name: HHPANELP2_2
var.labl: Panel woman from Phase 1 lives in this dwelling in Phase 2
var.txt: HHPANELP2 indicates whether a woman interviewed in Phase 1 was living in the dwelling in Phase 2.

var.name: HHTYPE_1
var.labl: Panel household type
var.txt:
HHTYPE reports the household's follow up type in Phase 2. The household could be the same as the Phase 1 household if at least one original resident was still living there. The household could be a replacement household sampled in areas of high household attrition. The household could also be the new household of a panel woman who moved within the study area between Phase 1 and Phase 2.
See the sample notes documentation for more information on the longitudinal data.

var.name: HHTYPE_2
var.labl: Panel household type
var.txt:
HHTYPE reports the household's follow up type in Phase 2. The household could be the same as the Phase 1 household if at least one original resident was still living there. The household could be a replacement household sampled in areas of high household attrition. The household could also be the new household of a panel woman who moved within the study area between Phase 1 and Phase 2.
See the sample notes documentation for more information on the longitudinal data.

var.name: HHSTATUS_1
var.labl: Phase 1 household status
var.txt: HHSTATUS reports the status of the Phase 1 household if they are no longer living in their previous dwelling at the time of the Phase 2 interview one year later.

var.name: HHSTATUS_2
var.labl: Phase 1 household status
var.txt: HHSTATUS reports the status of the Phase 1 household if they are no longer living in their previous dwelling at the time of the Phase 2 interview one year later.

var.name: HHREPLACED_1
var.labl: Household is replacement for attrition
var.txt: HHREPLACED indicates whether the person was a member of a household that was newly sampled for the Phase 2 longitudinal family planning survey due to more than 10 percent attrition within one EA since the Phase 1 survey round.

var.name: HHREPLACED_2
var.labl: Household is replacement for attrition
var.txt: HHREPLACED indicates whether the person was a member of a household that was newly sampled for the Phase 2 longitudinal family planning survey due to more than 10 percent attrition within one EA since the Phase 1 survey round.

var.name: SAMEDWELLING_1
var.labl: Living in same dwelling unit as Phase 1
var.txt: SAMEDWELLING indicates whether the person was living in the same dwelling in Phase 2 as they were in Phase 1 of the longitudinal family planning survey.

var.name: SAMEDWELLING_2
var.labl: Living in same dwelling unit as Phase 1
var.txt: SAMEDWELLING indicates whether the person was living in the same dwelling in Phase 2 as they were in Phase 1 of the longitudinal family planning survey.

var.name: HHOCCUPIED_1
var.labl: Dwelling unit is occupied
var.txt:
For households that are residing in the same dwelling unit as they were during Phase 1 of the survey, HHOCCUPIED indicates whether any people are currently living in this dwelling unit.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire.

var.name: HHOCCUPIED_2
var.labl: Dwelling unit is occupied
var.txt:
For households that are residing in the same dwelling unit as they were during Phase 1 of the survey, HHOCCUPIED indicates whether any people are currently living in this dwelling unit.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire.

var.name: HHMEMSTAT_1
var.labl: Status of household member from baseline survey
var.txt:
For household members who had been enumerated in a longitudinal household survey, HHMEMSTAT reports whether the household member was still a resident of the household in the follow-up survey, and if not, the reason why. The person could have been still a resident, moved away, died, or the interviewer might have been unable to find knowledgeable household members or neighbors to determine that person's status.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire.

catgry.labl: Moved out of household for school

var.name: HHMEMSTAT_2
var.labl: Status of household member from baseline survey
var.txt:
For household members who had been enumerated in a longitudinal household survey, HHMEMSTAT reports whether the household member was still a resident of the household in the follow-up survey, and if not, the reason why. The person could have been still a resident, moved away, died, or the interviewer might have been unable to find knowledgeable household members or neighbors to determine that person's status.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire.

catgry.labl: Moved out of household for school

var.name: HHMEMUPDATE_1
var.labl: Demographic data of household member updated
var.txt: For household members who were residents in both Phase 1 and Phase 2, HHMEMUPDATE indicates whether the household member's demographic information was updated between Phase 1 and Phase 2.

var.name: HHMEMUPDATE_2
var.labl: Demographic data of household member updated
var.txt: For household members who were residents in both Phase 1 and Phase 2, HHMEMUPDATE indicates whether the household member's demographic information was updated between Phase 1 and Phase 2.

var.name: HHNEWYR_1
var.labl: Household structure was built in past 12 months
var.txt: HHNEWYR indicates whether the dwelling the Phase 2 household was living in was constructed in the past 12 months.

var.name: HHNEWYR_2
var.labl: Household structure was built in past 12 months
var.txt: HHNEWYR indicates whether the dwelling the Phase 2 household was living in was constructed in the past 12 months.

var.name: HHVACANTWHY_1
var.labl: Reason for no people living in sampled dwelling
var.txt:
For dwelling units that were included in the Phase 1 (baseline) survey and do not currently have people living in them, HHVACANTWHY indicates why people are not currently living in the dwelling unit.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire.

catgry.labl: Phase 1 dwelling unit vacant or address not a dwelling unit
Phase 1 dwelling unit was not found

var.name: HHIDORIGP1DWELL_1
var.labl: Original dwelling identifier from Phase 1
var.txt: HHIDORIGP1DWELL is the original PMA dwelling identifier from the Phase 1 longitudinal family planning survey contained in the Phase 2. This variable identifies the physical space, not necessarily the household members. HHIDORIGP1DWELL is the same as HHIDORIGP1 if the individual lived in the same dwelling in both Phase 1 and Phase 2.
var.codInstr: This is a 50-digit numeric variable with 0 implied decimal places

var.name: HHIDORIGP1DWELL_2
var.labl: Original dwelling identifier from Phase 1
var.txt: HHIDORIGP1DWELL is the original PMA dwelling identifier from the Phase 1 longitudinal family planning survey contained in the Phase 2. This variable identifies the physical space, not necessarily the household members. HHIDORIGP1DWELL is the same as HHIDORIGP1 if the individual lived in the same dwelling in both Phase 1 and Phase 2.
var.codInstr: This is a 50-digit numeric variable with 0 implied decimal places

var.name: HHMEMPRESP1_1
var.labl: At least one original household member present
var.txt: HHMEMPRESP1 indicates whether at least one Phase 1 household member was still present in Phase 2.

var.name: HHMEMPRESP1_2
var.labl: At least one original household member present
var.txt: HHMEMPRESP1 indicates whether at least one Phase 1 household member was still present in Phase 2.

var.name: HHIDORIGP1
var.labl: Original household identifier from Phase 1
var.txt: HHIDORIGP1 is the original PMA household identifier from the Phase 1 longitudinal family planning survey contained in the Phase 2 data for persons who also appeared in the Phase 1 household roster. HHIDORIGP1 is the same as HHIDORIGP1DWELL if the individual lived in the same dwelling in both Phase 1 and Phase 2. If the person has moved to a different dwelling, HHIDORIGP1 in Phase 2 is the same as HHIDORIG in the Phase 1 data, allowing users to match the person to their household in Phase 1.
var.codInstr: This is a 50-digit numeric variable with 0 implied decimal places
